nodes.text: Decisions that maximize time-average growth of wealth (growth optimality) can be formulated as expected utility maximization by identifying the utility function with the ergodicity transformation of the underlying wealth dynamics
Ergodicity economics (EE) models wealth as a stochastic process and proposes agents maximize the time-average growth rate of wealth rather than expectation values over ensembles
Expected utility theory (EUT) models decisions by maximization of expected changes in a nonlinear utility function u(x), interpreted as psychological risk preferences

For a given wealth dynamic, an ergodicity transformation u(x) may be chosen so that the long-time average rate r_bar of changes in u equals the expectation value of that rate, making r an ergodic observable

All invertible utility functions correspond to wealth dynamics for which expected-utility maximization is equivalent to time-average growth maximization; conversely, any u(x) that yields additive stationary independent increments (Brownian motion with drift) makes EUT dynamically interpretable

EE and EUT differ conceptually: expectation values are ensemble averages relevant to hypothetical collectives, while time averages are mechanistically relevant to single agents following one trajectory

Mathematical condition: u(t) must be a stochastic process with stationary independent additive increments (a Levy process); with continuous paths this implies u follows Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW, ensuring limit r_bar exists and equals a_u

Decision criterion: choose the stochastic process x(t) that maximizes the long-time limit of delta u over time, equivalently maximizing the time-average growth rate r_bar when u has the required stochastic properties

Theorem: For any invertible u(x) satisfying smoothness, application of Ito's lemma to du = a_u dt + b_u dW yields a corresponding Ito SDE dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW, so optimizing expected changes in u is equivalent to optimizing time-average growth under the induced dx

Given a general Ito dynamic dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW, necessary and sufficient consistency conditions for existence of a u(x) with constant a_u and b_u are bu = b_x(x) u'(x) and a_u = a_x(x) u'(x) + (1/2) b_x(x)^2 u''(x), from which u can be constructed when solvable

Examples mapping utilities to dynamics: linear u(x)=x -> additive Brownian motion; logarithmic u(x)=ln x -> geometric Brownian motion; square-root u(x)=sqrt(x) -> mixed additive-multiplicative SDE with drift and sqrt noise

Example inverse mapping: dynamic dx = (a_u/b_u e^{-x} - 1/2 e^{-2x}) dt + e^{-x} dW is consistent and yields u(x) = b_u e^{x} + C, a convex (risk-seeking under EUT) utility whose u(t) is Brownian with drift

Wealth distribution derivation: since u(t) is normal N(a_u t, b_u^2 t), the induced wealth distribution P_x(x,t) is Pu(u(x),t) times du/dx, giving explicit time-dependent wealth distributions for the mapped dynamics

Implication: because wealth dynamics are exogenous, the apparent utility function (and thus observed risk preferences) can be predicted a priori from dynamics, and preferences will change if dynamics change; experiments show dynamics strongly determine behavior

Formal requirement: utility functions should be unbounded for the dynamic interpretation because bounded invertible u(x) are inconsistent with u following Brownian motion with drift and would imply pathological finite-time singularities or bounded time
